conclusion: The problem involves understanding the relationship between volume, temperature, and pressure for an ideal gas, using the given initial and final conditions to calculate the pressure at the final state.
The graph shows the relationship between volume (V) and temperature (T) for an ideal gas. Line segment AB is parallel to the V-axis, and the extension of BC passes through the origin.
At state A, the volume \( V_A = V_0 \), temperature \( T_A = T_0 \), and pressure \( p_A = p_0 \).
At state B, the volume is \( 2V_0 \) because line segment AB is parallel to the V-axis.
Using the ideal gas law \( PV = nRT \), the initial state at A is described as \( V_A = V_0 \), \( T_A = T_0 \), and \( p_A = p_0 \).
At state B, the volume is \( V_B = 2V_0 \).
The number of moles \( n \) can be calculated using the ideal gas law: \( n = \frac{PV}{RT} \). At state A, \( n_0 = \frac{p_0 \times V_0}{R \times T_0} \).
At state B, the number of moles \( n_B = \frac{p_0 \times 2V_0}{R \times T_0} \).
Using the ideal gas law at state B, the pressure \( p_B \) can be calculated as \( p_B = \frac{n_B \times R \times T_0}{2V_0} \).
Substitute the values into the equation for \( p_B \): \( p_B = \frac{\left(\frac{p_0 \times 2V_0}{R \times T_0}\right) \times R \times T_0}{2V_0} \).
The pressure at state B is \( p_B = p_0 \).
